REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:

CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None.

INDICATION: Run over by car.

COMPARISON: None.

TECHNIQUE: MDCT-acquired axial images of the chest, abdomen and
pelvis were obtained with IV contrast. Multiplanar reformatted
images were also displayed.

CT OF THE CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST: There is no evidence of
traumatic aortic injury. There is a small-to-moderate sized
left-sided pneumothorax. Severe bullous changes are noted within
both lungs, most prominent at the right apex. Increased ground
glass opacities seen at the lung bases, possibly representing
contusion or aspiration. No pathologically enlarged mediastinal,
hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy is identified. Multiple
bilateral rib fractures are identified. Fractures are seen in
the left second, third, fourth, fifth (2 fractures), sixth (2
fractures), seventh, eighth, and ninth ribs. Fracture is also
seen in the right fourth, fifth, eighth, and possibly ninth
ribs.

CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST: The liver, gallbladder,
spleen, pancreas, adrenal glands, and kidneys appear
unremarkable. There is no evidence of free air or free fluid
within the abdomen. Visualized portions of bowel appear
unremarkable.

CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST: The rectum, sigmoid appear
unremarkable. The bladder appears decompressed, likely secondary
to Foley catheterization. There is no evidence of free fluid
within the pelvis. No pelvic bone fractures are identified.
Small amount of stranding is seen in the left flank/buttock area
consistent with a small soft tissue hematoma.

BONE WINDOWS: Multiple bilateral rib fractures as described. No
suspicious lytic or blastic lesions are identified.

Multiplanar reformatted images confirm the axial findings.

IMPRESSION:
1. Mild-to-moderate left-sided pneumothorax with multiple
bilateral rib fractures as described above. No evidence of acute
solid organ injury.
2. Poorly defined ground glass opacity is seen predominantly at
the lung bases, possibly representing contusion versus
aspiration.
3. Emphysematous changes with severe bullous changes most
prominent at the right apex.


Brief Hospital Course:
Patient admitted to the trauma service. He was admitted to the
Trauma ICU for close observation and was eventually transferred
to the regular nursing unit. A mild to moderate sized left
pneumothorax was identified on CT of chest; serial chest
radiographs were stable and did not reveal an increase in this.
He is experiencing pain from his multiple rib fractures; his
pain is being controlled with po Dilaudid and Motrin 600 qid.
His diet was advanced and he is tolerating this well.

He was instructed to follow up with his primary doctor in the
next 2-3 weeks and to follow up with Trauma Clinic as needed for
issues concerning [**Last Name (un) **] related to his crash.
